plain: The user's favourite genre is likely to be fantasy, as The Mists of Avalon and A Midsummer Night's Dream are both set in mythical times and places. The user's favourite kind of plot is likely to be character-driven, as The Mists of Avalon, The Scarlet Letter, The God of Small Things, To Kill a Mockingbird, The Rose That Grew From Concrete, The World According to Garp, Rule of the Bone, and The Grapes of Wrath all feature complex and well-developed characters. The user's favourite setting is likely to be historical or mythical, as The Mists of Avalon, The Scarlet Letter, The God of Small Things, To Kill a Mockingbird, The Rose That Grew From Concrete, The World According to Garp, Rule of the Bone, and The Grapes of Wrath all take place in different times and places. The user's favourite writing style is likely to be descriptive and lyrical, as The Mists of Avalon, The Scarlet Letter, The God of Small Things, To Kill a Mockingbird, The Rose That Grew From Concrete, The World According to Garp, Rule of the Bone, and The Grapes of Wrath all feature rich and evocative language. The user's favourite length is likely to be novel-length, as all of the books mentioned are novels. The user's favourite topic is likely to be social justice, as The Scarlet Letter, The God of Small Things, To Kill a Mockingbird, The Rose That Grew From Concrete, The World According to Garp, Rule of the Bone, and The Grapes of Wrath all deal with important social issues. The user's favourite pacing is likely to be slow and contemplative, as The Mists of Avalon, The Scarlet Letter, The God of Small Things, To Kill a Mockingbird, The Rose That Grew From Concrete, The World According to Garp, Rule of the Bone, and The Grapes of Wrath all take their time developing their stories and characters. The user's favourite narrative structure is likely to be third-person omniscient, as The Mists of Avalon, The Scarlet Letter, The God of Small Things, To Kill a Mockingbird, The Rose That Grew From Concrete, The World According to Garp, Rule of the Bone, and The Grapes of Wrath all feature a broad perspective on their stories and characters.
